subject: Programming
title: Hard Drives and Permanent Storage
description: A 60-second lesson on Hard Drives and Permanent Storage.

hook.text: A hard drive spins a metal platter at 7,200 RPM while a needle reads magnetic dots.

buildup.text: Data is written by magnetizing tiny regions on the platter. Each region stores a single bit.

discovery.text: Unlike RAM, hard drives keep data without power. Your files survive shutdowns and reboots.

twist.text: Mechanical parts wear out. A single head crash can destroy years of data in milliseconds.

climax.text: SSDs replaced spinning platters with flash memory â€” no moving parts, faster, more durable.

punchline.text: Storage keeps memories even after the power dies.

quiz.question: What advantage do SSDs have over traditional hard drives?
options: No moving parts, faster and more durable
